EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This IRM supersedes the information in IRM 8.20.2 dated September 25th, 2013, Appeals Processing Manual, IDRS Transcripts and Automated Systems.

Transcripts and Automated Systems 8.20.2

) Account and Processing Support (APS) is responsible for establishing, main- taining and closing cases in Appeals. APS uses various systems to complete these tasks and IDRS is one of the most important. (
) IDRS allows extensive research of taxpayer account information. IDRS infor- mation is classified as Master File (MF) or Non-Master File (NMF). (

) APS Tax Examiners must check IDRS each time the case is handled out the Appeals process. APS Tax Examiners must use IDRS to verify the following types of information: a. assessments/overassessments b. payments c. module balances d. filing dates e. tentative allowances f. restricted interest transactions g. amended returns filed h. frozen refunds (
) Every return or document input through the Automated Data Processing system is assigned a document locator number (DLN) for control and identity purposes. The DLN is

digits in length, including a two-digit prefix, which identifies the Campus or Area Office that handled the input. The fourteenth (last) digit is the year of processing assigned by the Campus computer at time of the original input. Examples: a.

is updated annually and provides detailed information on command codes used by Appeals. Refer to IRM
, IDRS Terminal Responses, Section Titles and Command Codes for IDRS Terminal Responses. (

) Research of all IMF and BMF accounts is accomplished through the Data Retrieval System (IDRS). IDRS is a system that enables employees in the Campuses and the Area Offices to have instantaneous visual access to certain taxpayer accounts. (

) The following command codes generate various types of Master File data available on IDRS: a. TXMOD with the A definer (TXMODA) contains more detailed and more current account information than any other single command code. It includes all notice statuses, history items, control bases, and pending transactions. TXMOD information is only available when there is current activity on an account. If a TXMOD is not available, command code MFREQC is used to obtain the TXMOD. b. IMFOL provides read-only access to the Individual Master File (IMF). It also provides a listing of the modules removed to the retention register. Internal Revenue Manual
allows extensive research of taxpayer account information. IDRS infor- is classified as Master File (MF) or Non-Master File (NMF).

Every return or document input through the Automated Data Processing system is assigned a document locator number (DLN) for control and identity purposes. The DLN is 14 digits in length, including a two-digit prefix, which identifies the Campus or Area Office that handled the input. The fourteenth (last) digit is the year of processing assigned by the Campus computer at the time of the original input. Examples:

a. TXMOD with the A definer (TXMODA) contains more detailed and more current account information than any other single command code. It includes all notice statuses, history items, control bases, and pending transactions. TXMOD information is only available when there is current activity on an account. If a TXMOD is not available, command code MFREQC is used to obtain the TXMOD. b. IMFOL provides read
only access to the Individual Master File (IMF). It also provides a listing of the modules removed to the retention register.
IMFOL provides read-only access to the Individual Master File (IMF). It also provides a listing of the modules removed to the retention

Account and Processing Support APS Tax Examiners use command code IMFOL with definers R and T. IMFOL with definer H provides a Help Screen. IMFOL should be used in lieu of MFTRA where possible. c. BMFOL provides research of nationwide entity and tax data information posted to the Business Master File (BMF). It also allows research of modules dropped to retention in

and later. APS Tax Examiners use command code BMFOL with definers R and T. BMFOL with definer H provides a Help Screen. BMFOL should be used in lieu of MFTRA possible. d. MFTRA provides a hard copy of the account information. See IRM

for a complete listing of available MFTRA transcripts. e. MFTRAX provides a literal transcript of the transactions occurring on an account. It can be used when taxpayers request copies of their account information. f. ENMOD provides entity information. It includes the taxpayer(s) name(s), prior names, addresses, and filing status history. g. SUMRY provides a summary of active tax years and accounts. It tax years with amounts due, returns due, and any accounts with frozen credits or refunds to be issued. If only one year is active on IDRS, TXMOD will be displayed instead of SUMRY. (

) ANMF provides the capability for nationwide on-line research and on-line script requests for NMF accounts. NMF is used to process returns that be processed on the Master File (MF). Note: Unit Ledger Cards (ULCs) must still be requested for accounts closed to ANMF. Use Form
, Information or Certified Transcript Request to request a ULC. (

) The following are some of the reasons processing cannot be done on the a. New tax laws require immediate implementation but time does not extensive modifications to the Automatic Data Processing (ADP) b. Immediate legal assessments (within

hours) must be made but MF is too slow to post assessments. c. Transactions required on a MF account are in excess of the number of transactions that the MF account can systemically handle (overflow accounts). d. Account balances are too large for the MF to systemically handle. e. Reversals of Erroneous Abatements (TC
) cannot be made because the Assessment Statute Expiration Date (ASED) has expired. (

, Business Tax Returns and Non-Master File Accounts, for additional information on creating and assessing Non-Master File accounts and the use of ANMF. (
) Copies of NMF transcripts should not be given to taxpayers. Serious issues may result because of information included in the cross reference history section of the transcript.

is input to Master File. NMF accounts with balances due have a TC
input, which freezes and refunds to the taxpayer from the Master File. (

identifies the Campus that placed the freeze. Sometimes an account will show more than one TC
, especially when a case has been transferred from one Campus to another. In this use the last posted TC
to identify the Campus currently holding the There is another indicator, other than Campus locator,

) MFT
is an IMF master file tax (MFT) account code. MFT
is used for sessments against an individual taxpayer on a joint module and is generated by one or more of the following: (cid:
) Bankruptcy - Either spouse claims a bankruptcy (cid:
) CDP - When only one spouse is liable for a joint liability and declared as currently not collectible (Transaction Code
on module) while collection continues against the related spouse (cid:
) Offer in Compromise (OIC) - Either spouse makes an offer on a liability (cid:
) Tax Court - Either spouse petitions the court (cid:
) Innocent Spouse - An assessment is made against a joint module but spouse is relieved of the liability fully or partially (cid:
) Taxpayer Assistance Order - Either spouse files Form
, Application Taxpayer Assistance Order (
) There are three types of MFT
accounts:
Split/Transfer - MFT
accounts created or in process prior to January
See IRM
for further information on identifying these accounts.
Mirrored - MFT
accounts created on or after January
: Bank- ruptcy by only one spouse, innocent spouse claim, OIC filed by only one spouse, joint OIC defaulted by one spouse, or Form
filed by only spouse. See IRM
for further information on identifying these accounts.
Exam/Appeals/AUR - Agreed to tax adjustment by only one spouse, or Court petition filed or defaulted by only one spouse. MFT
modules are created but not mirrored. See IRM
for further information on identifying these accounts. (
) MFT
contains split spousal assessments previously processed to NMF which meet one or more of the following conditions: (cid:
) Collection action is prohibited against one spouse. (cid:
) Extensions or suspensions result in different Collection Statute Expiration Dates (CSEDs) or Assessment Statute Expiration Dates (ASEDs) for each spouse. (cid:
) Each spouse is liable for different amounts. (

8.20 Account and Processing Support
Account and Processing Support (
) As of January
, Master File programming for the MFT
allows the systemic “mirroring” of the MFT
module. Mirror modules are created in certain events occur that may result in one or both spouses being fully or partially liable. (
) The mirroring process creates two MFT

accounts; one for each spouse’s Social Security Number (SSN). It provides a greater ability to systemically handle separate treatment of spouses; while maintaining a necessary cross- referencing capability. Some modules will have conditions that prevent mirroring or cause the mirroring process to occur at a later stage. (
) The purpose of mirroring a joint MFT
module into separate, but identical MFT

modules is to allow for the correct computation of each taxpayer’s lection Statute Expiration Date (CSED). Mirroring will also allow collection activity to continue for the nonrequesting spouse (NRS). (
) The mirroring process occurs through a series of transactions: a. Two TC
s are input on the MFT
account. Each TC
will a XREF-TIN field entry, one with the primary SSN as the TIN and the second with the secondary SSN as the cross-reference b. The TC
action code (AC) of

account will indicate the account is mirrored on MFT

account to the two MFT

accounts. An M- Freeze is generated on all three accounts. Credits are generated to all three accounts, making them appear to be in zero balance. Caution: The account is not full paid. Any balance due will be re-established

) The Appeals employee is responsible for determining what assessments overassessments have been made to the taxpayer’s account. This is necessary for determining “tax as previously adjusted” on the audit statement or statutory notice of deficiency. (
) Any debit or credit module balance should be reconciled to determine what transactions generated it. The modules are systemically established but mirrored. (

for additional information. (

8.20 Account and Processing Support (APS)

Account and Processing Support (APS) uses various automated systems, in addition to IDRS, to establish, maintain and close cases in Appeals inventory. This subsection provides a descriptive explanation of some of those systems. AIMS (Audit Information Management System): a. Appeals receives some cases from Compliance that may be controlled AIMS. These cases may have been audited for possible additional tax penalty liabilities. See IRM
, AIMS Processing, for information relating to AIMS processing of examination returns. See also Document

b. Each AIMS input form is identified by a number, a command code, and a color code as explained in text below. The Audit Information Systems Manual contains instructions and screen examples for all AIMS input codes. The terminal operator uses the command code to tell the terminal what information is being input and how the data file should the information. c. Listed below is a description of the AIMS command codes most often used by Appeals: (cid:
) AMCLS A/F/I/S/U - used to adjust, correct or close returns on AIMS (
) (cid:
) AMSTUA - updates the record to an active Appeals status (
or
) from
(cid:
) AMSTUB - Appeals Update Command code AMSTUB - changes the and statute date of any return already in an Appeals status (cid:
) AM
A - used to establish a master file record on the AIMS database (cid:

) Tax Court website. Consult the Tax Court website at http:// www.ustaxcourt.gov/ to resolve questions concerning how the court characterized a particular document for filing. (
) IAT (Integrated Automation Technologies) is used to complete various forms, input adjustments on IDRS, as a record of suspense cases, and to add history statuses on IDRS. (

) IMS (Issue Management System). The IMS is Large Business and Internation- al’s (LB&I’s) case management system. Appeals’ use of IMS became mandatory for working all LB&I cases, as well as most Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) Estate and Gift (E&G) and Excise cases in December The Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS) will remain the Appeals system of record for case management and recording time on cases. For step by step instructions for IMS, please refer to the Appeals Training Module for APS, ELMS course number

The primary role of the APS Tax Examiner in IMS is to assign a case, re-assign a case, or re-open a closed case. The APS Tax Examiner has permissions to view Appeals cases to be assigned, opened (currently assigned), and closed on the Appeals portal. An APS Tax Examiner may assign an Appeals case to an Appeals Team Manager (ATM), re-assign an open Appeals case, or re-open a closed Appeals case on the portal. An O
ine

is required to gain access to IMS. Each user should request the “IMS-PRODUCTION-LMSB USER ACCESS” application and add a statement indicating “An Examination Returns Control System (ERCS) ID is required.”

This glossary defines various terms and phrases used in Appeals. Each definition is given in broad terms to provide an overview of the subject. Document 6209 contains a glossary of commonly used IRS terms.

Term Definition AIMS Audit Information Management System used to control tax periods the case moves through the Compliance (formerly Examination) Appeals process. ASED Assessment Statute Expiration Date. The last date an assessment be made. Normally 3 years from the due date or received date of return, whichever is later. Abatement A credit adjustment to a taxpayer’s account Accruing A term used to describe how interest accumulates. Advance Payment A payment made by the taxpayer. The payment cannot be until a final determination of the taxpayer’s liability. However, the taxpayer receives interest on the payment if they receive a refund IRS. Appeals Office Code (AOC) Each Appeals Office is assigned a 2 digit code. This code is used designate a location of the primary office. The code is used on AIMS, ISTS. If a “1” precedes the 2 digit code for nondocketed cases, and a precedes the 2 digit code for docketed cases. This code is also referred to as the AIMS Office Code. See Document 6209. Assessment A debit adjustment to a taxpayer’s account which triggers a bill for penalties, and/or interest owed. CSED Collection Statute Expiration Date. Normally 10 years from the an assessment of tax. Case A case is used to describe a file in which all tax periods for one ance report are included. For example, if 3 years for one taxpayer appealed, they constitute a case. Cash Bond A payment made by the taxpayer as a deposit. As long as it is on deposit with the Internal Revenue service the TP is not charged interest. Claim for Refund Claim for refund is a written request by the taxpayer for a refund previously paid. Closing Code This codes designates the type of closing action taken on a case. Command Code This is a code used by IDRS terminal operators to properly changes or provide information on a taxpayer’s account. Consent A form signed by the taxpayer to extend the time in which the IRS to adjust the taxpayer’s account.
designate a location of the primary office. The code is used on ACDS, AIMS, ISTS. If a “
” precedes the
digit code for nondocketed cases, and a “
” precedes the
digit code for docketed cases. This code is also referred to as the AIMS Office Code. See Document
A debit adjustment to a taxpayer’s account which triggers a bill for tax, penalties, and/or interest owed.
Collection Statute Expiration Date. Normally 10 years from the date of an assessment of tax.
A case is used to describe a file in which all tax periods for one ance report are included. For example, if 3 years for one taxpayer are appealed, they constitute a case.

8.20.2-2 (Cont. 1) (10-15-2014) of Appeals Terms Term Definition Decision Letter Issued when a CDP request is filed late. The CSED is not suspended and the taxpayer does not have judicial review rights and Appeals does not retain jurisdiction. Determination Letter This is a letter issued to the taxpayer on an Innocent Spouse or Collec- tion Due Process Case. There may be different suspense periods in which the taxpayer has to petition the court. DLN Document Locator Number. A controlled number assigned to every return or document input through the ADP system. See Document 6209 for additional information on the structure. Docket Number (DKTNO) A number assigned to each petition by the Tax Court or complaint by the District Court in response to a notice of deficiency, determination letter or notice of claim disallowance. eCase Functionality that provides electronic transfer of data from Appeals suppliers (AIMS/ERCS, AOIC, ACS and ICS.) Employer Identification An assigned nine digit number to identify a business tax account. Number (EIN) Fiscal Year This refers to the 12 month processing cycles/business year of an entity. All fiscal years are referred to by their ending month. Freeze Codes Alpha codes applied to a master file account on IDRS which identifies specific conditions. Restricts normal computer operations. See Document 6209 for additional information on AIMS and IDRS freeze codes. Installment Agreement A contract the taxpayer signs agreeing to make monthly payments or other periodic payment of a specific amount on their tax bill. Internal Revenue Code The part of the United States Codes which contains the tax laws. Internal Revenue Manual The official source of procedures and instructions for Internal Revenue Service functions. Master File Tax (MFT) Two digit number which identifies the type of tax. Name Control Used for AIMS processing and consists of four significant letters of the taxpayer’s name. Offer in Compromise (OIC) The taxpayer offers to pay a part of the tax due. The case can be based on either doubt as to liability (Examination source), doubt as to collectiblity (Collection source), or Effective Tax Administration (Excep- tional Circumstances). Premature Referral Describes the action taken on a case forwarded to Appeals before the issues were properly developed. Pro Se Describes a taxpayer who represents himself/herself during the Appeals process.
